children.subject: Thanks a lot! Do you know any other courses that prepare you for CS 189?
Can't say for sure since I haven't taken many courses related to 189, but I've heard 127 might be helpful if you wanna be more prepared.

Hey there, I know this doesn't answer your question, but I believe you don't need any of those classes for 189, especially with Prof. Shewchuk teaching. I think some basic understanding of gradients and linear algebra and maybe some probability (to the level of understanding pdfs) will be fully enough for preparation. By this I mean that you probably need ee16a and cs70, and taking math 53 would be cool if you want to be extra prepared.

From personal experience, I only took 126 out of the classes you mentioned before 189 (in Spring 19) and didn't find 126 very applicable at all, except for a lecture or two. I believe that 189 is designed in a way so that even if you don't know stuff going in, you'll be able to learn it at a reasonable speed without feeling behind. I didn't get an A+ though, if that's what your aim is. In that case being more prepared would be safer lol.

I haven't heard anybody say 188 is good for 189 and I would disagree with anybody that says so; it's maybe helpful for one lecture in 189 on backprop and that's about it (188 is still an interesting course on its own though). 

126 is definitely harder and covers more than Stat 134, but the benefit of taking 126 conditional on having 134 already for 189 is not that high imo.

127 is probably helpful for 189 but I took it after I took 189, and while taking 189 I didn't feel like I especially needed it (but it would have been more helpful than the other classes).

But the real question is, why are you making your schedule revolve around doing well in 189? If you want to do research or finding a data science job people would probably recommend different things in each case.

You have enough background for Shewchuck's 189 already. 134 is more than enough probability knowledge for the class, and 110 is easily enough linear algebra knowledge. Taking 127 concurrently is helpful and provides an interesting perspective to a lot of the material imo, but it's definitely not a prerequisite. 170 and 188 aren't really related to 189.

history.content: I asked a peer advisor and the peer advisor said that the last part of 188 is helpful but is not necessary. I asked a TA and the TA said 188 is not necessary. The TA didn't take 188 or look 188 material before 189 and did well in 189. It's not necessary to take 126 after 134, especially for Shewchuk's 189. 189 and 127 concurrently is indeed good.

I heard EECS 126, EECS 127, CS 188 are good courses for CS 189.

I also heard taken 189 and 127 concurrently is good.

I have taken CS 170, Stats 134, and Math 110, any suggestions on which courses to be taken if I want to take CS 189 in Spring 2021? (2 semesters away) Thanks!
history.subject: Which courses are best preparation for CS 189?

history.content:
I heard EECS 126, EECS 127, CS 188 are good courses for CS 189.

I also heard taken 189 and 127 concurrently is good.
